Review Recent advances in bio-glycerol valorization to glycerol carbonate by heterogenous base-catalyzed transesterification Shalini Sahani a Siddhi Jaiswal b Sadhna Mishra c Yogesh Chandra Sharma d Sung Soo Han a ⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering, Yeungnam University, 280 Daehak-ro, Gyeongsan 38541, South Korea School of Chemical Engineering Yeungnam University 280 Daehak-ro Gyeongsan 38541 South Korea aSchool of Chemical Engineering, Yeungnam University, 280 Daehak-ro, Gyeongsan 38541, South Korea b Nari Shiksha Niketan PG College, Lucknow University, Lucknow, India Nari Shiksha Niketan PG College Lucknow University Lucknow India bNari Shiksha Niketan PG College, Lucknow University, Lucknow, India c Faculty of Agricultural Sciences, GLA University, Mathura 281406, India Faculty of Agricultural Sciences GLA University Mathura 281406 India cFaculty of Agricultural Sciences, GLA University, Mathura 281406, India d Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology (Banaras Hindu University), Varanasi, India Department of Chemistry Indian Institute of Technology (Banaras Hindu University) Varanasi India dDepartment of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology (Banaras Hindu University), Varanasi, India ⁎ Corresponding author. World biomass valorization has been tremendously boosted by the production of biofuels like biodiesel and hence bio-glycerol, and the bio-glycerol produced can be modified to produce a plethora of useful derivatives. In particular, glycerol carbonate (GLC) is considered one of the most important value-added products due to its many applications in the pharmaceutical and cosmetic industries and others. In this review, we describe heterogeneous catalytic synthetic routes designed to maximize glycerol conversion (GC) and GLC selectivity. Notably, heterogeneous base-catalyzed carboxylation (transesterification) between glycerol and dimethyl carbonate has been identified as a safer and economically viable means of synthesizing GLC. Particularly, alkali and alkaline metal oxide-based hybrid base catalysts are the best candidates for GLC production. Additionally, waste-derived base catalysts are preferred to make sure the process is more cost-effective. Also, only the appropriate amount of basic active sites ends up in the carboxylation of glycerol successfully with methanol as the only side-product. Otherwise, exorbitant basic sites might lead to GLC decomposition to glycidol and reduce GLC selectivity. Later, kinetic and thermodynamic considerations along with TOFs and E-factors are also discussed to provide insight into reaction pathways. This study provides a summary of recent literature on the large-scale production of GLC and of studies on waste-derived solid catalysts, which make the process more cost-effective. In a nutshell, we highlight the environmental and cost benefits conferred by the use of bifunctional efficient heterogeneous catalysts to subsequently produce biodiesel and GLC using coupling transesterification reactions that produce and valorize glycerol simultaneously. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Glycerol carbonate Heterogeneous catalyst Dimethyl carbonate Kinetics Thermodynamics E-factor Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Glycerol carbonate (GLC, also known as glycerol 1,2-carbonate) is considered an important chemical compound with various applications due to its environmental benignity, low toxicity, and biodegradability [1,2]. It is derived from glycerol, a natural byproduct of biodiesel production, and exhibits unique properties that make it valuable in different industries. The hydroxyl and cyclic carbonate functional groups confer upon this five-membered ring glycerol derivative versatility and chemical reactivity [3]. Furthermore, its chemically active functional groups enable the production of many value-added products [4] GLC is thermally stable and has a relatively high boiling point [5,6] (BP, 110–115 °C at 0.1 mbar), low volatility (vapor pressure of 8 mbar at 177 °C), a high dielectric constant (ε: 82.7), and is non-flammable (with flash point>204 °C) and water-soluble [7–9]. It is a platform material used for the synthesis of several organic compounds, cement composite aggregates, solvents, surfactants, urethane monomers for polyurethane production, plant bolsters, cosmetics, high-purity mono glycerol, hyperbranched aliphatic polyethers, and electrolytes in Li-ion batteries (Fig. 1 a) [10,11]. While GLC has many useful applications, its general use and relevance may change as research and technology advances grow. GLC's importance is projected to grow as companies strive to develop more sustainable and ecologically friendly alternatives, owing to its potential contributions to green chemistry and a more sustainable future. GLC was first described in the late 19th century when it was originally produced by reacting phosgene with glycerol [12]. Industrial production of GLC began to take off in the middle of the 20th century [5,12,13]. Traditional methods included reacting phosgene with glycerol at high temperatures and pressures, which raised serious safety and environmental concerns [13]. Therefore, more environmentally friendly and sustainable methods have been recently developed [7,13–15]. Several catalytic methods have been used to produce greener, safer alternatives. Currently, dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is the preferred carbonate source for the transesterification of glycerol, and over the past decade, new catalysts have been developed [3,5,9,13,15–21] with improved efficiency and sustainability (Fig. 2 ). For a long time, the conventional Bronsted acid-catalyzed transesterification of glycerol was one of the most extensively used procedures, although it is usually limited by equipment corrosion, difficulty in catalyst recovery, and low conversion and selectivity [22]. In recent years, base catalysts have been widely used in the transesterification of GLC. Although homogeneous base catalyst performed well in transesterification, it was still challenged with the same issue of catalyst separation, recovery, and reusability [12]. Esteban et al. [23] reported GC of 95% in 4 h at 60 °C with an excess of DMC to glycerol of 3 to 1 and 2500 ppm of CH3OK. Similarly, Pan et al. [24] achieved the maximum 77% GC at moderate reaction conditions (54.3 mmol glycerol; 162.9 mmol DMC; 10 ml CH3OH, 0.2 g NaOH at 70 °C for 2 h). Owing to incomplete GC and reusability, homogeneous catalysts were soon rejected, and heterogeneous catalysts were sought as an alternative. As a result, heterogeneous base catalysts have received far greater attention due to their evident advantages over homogeneous base catalysts in the transformation of glycerol, particularly in industry. The year-wise progress in the application of heterogeneous catalysts has been shown in Fig. 2. Recently, Yu et al. [25] employed a 25 mol% Na/La2O3 catalyst and achieved the highest 85%GC and 60%GLC yield at 70 °C in 2 h. Another study [3] reported the usage of 5% CaO-modified sodium aluminate (NA5Ca) and a 45% glycerol template by weight of NA5Ca (NA5Ca- 45 G). The maximal GLC yield of NA5Ca-45 G was stated to be 90.5% with 100% selectivity by using a 30 wt.% of NA5Ca-45 G by weight of glycerol reactant, a glycerol: DMC molar ratio of 1:4, a reaction temperature of 70°C, and a reaction duration of 3 h. Currently, researchers are focusing on alkali/alkaline metals-based hybrid nanocomposites for GC valorization to GLC due to abundant reaction sites with enormous surface area. Despite these developments in heterogeneous catalysis, there is still a need to study and develop novel catalysts with improved activity, selectivity, and stability for GLC synthesis [25–32,30] The discovery of efficient and cost-effective catalysts for the conversion of glycerol and DMC into GLC continues to be a key challenge. Aside from it, many mechanical and chemical elements must be properly handled for large-scale GLC production. Understanding the complex chemical processes involved in the heterogeneous catalytic synthesis of GLC is critical. Detailed mechanistic investigations can provide insights into reaction kinetics and affecting factors, resulting in improved catalyst design and reaction optimization [31,33,34]. It is critical to develop efficient and scalable reactor topologies to economically produce GLC on a wide scale. Also, it is critical to investigate the production of undesirable by-products during GLC synthesis to decrease waste and optimize yield. Understanding the parameters that influence by-product generation can help in the development of catalysts and reaction conditions that favor the target product. Investigating catalyst deactivation mechanisms and developing effective regeneration methods are critical for extending catalyst's lifespan and lowering operational expenses [1,8,35]. To verify that the process adheres to green chemistry principles, it is necessary to assess the sustainability of the entire process, including raw material procurement and energy use. Addressing these research gaps could lead to major advances in heterogeneous catalyzed GLC synthesis, making it more efficient, sustainable, and commercially viable. This review article provides a critical valuation of the latest trends in GLC production via carboxylation using heterogeneous catalysts [3,12,36,37]. Various important reaction parameters are discussed along with possible reactor designs. In addition, the mechanism of carboxylation is described based on the most recent observations. Finally, research gaps and future aspects are presented. 2 GLC production GLC is mainly produced through the carboxylation of glycerol [35] which is synthesized by the high-pressure cleavage of fatty acids, hydroxylation of propylene, transesterification of triglyceride, or as a by-product of saponification [13]. The carboxylation of glycerol involves an ester exchange reaction between glycerol and the carbonate source [38]. The common carbonate sources are phosgene, CO/CO2 [39,40], urea [41–43], and organic carbonate supplements such as DMC [38,44,45], diethyl carbonate (DEC) [46,47], propylene carbonate (PC) [48] and ethylene carbonate (EC) [23,26,49] (Fig. 3 ). Different carbonate sources undergo different reaction pathways to produce GLC as summarized in Table 1 . Conventionally, glycerol was converted to GLC by the carbonylation of glycerol using phosgene which is extremely harmful and carcinogenic to human health. Hence its application was soon abandoned. Thereafter, the use of CO for glycerol carbonylation was also rejected due to the high pressure required and the toxicity of CO [50,51]. Subsequently, CO2 was found to be a suitable source for the synthesis of GLC [32,52] with an atom utilization of 87% and water as the sole byproduct. The direct carbonylation of glycerol using subcritical CO2 was achieved using nBu2SnO, nBu2Sn(OMe)2, CeO2/Al2O3, or CeO2/Nb2O5 as catalysts but with poor GC [50] due to kinetic and thermodynamic limitations caused by the inert character of CO2. However, the reaction rate can be promoted by using a combination of coupling reagents and catalysts. Liu et al. [50] reported enhanced catalytic performance (36.3% GLC yield) for Zr-doped CeO2 in the presence of 2-cyanopyridine as a coupling agent in DMF. Su et al. [53] described a metal and solvent-free method for the 2-cyanopyridine catalyzed conversion of CO2 and glycerol to GLC as presented in Fig. 4 . In this multistep process, 2-cyanopyridine firstly activates CO2 to form a five-membered ring chemical intermediate, i.e. picolinamide which then reacts with glycerol to form GLC. Notably, this multistep reaction achieved a GLC yield of only 18.7% under optimum conditions. Nonetheless, this chemical route is viewed optimistically though it remains a considerable research challenge. Similarly, a one-pot reaction between glycerol and CO2 was performed using propylene oxide as a coupling agent using alkali metal oxides as catalysts [20]. However, epoxide reactivity can be a limiting factor in this situation [54]. For example, some epoxides barely react with glycerol and CO2. In addition, one-pot reactions may also result in side reactions that reduce GLC yields, e.g., some epoxides may undergo ring-opening with glycerol to form unwanted by-products, which are difficult to remove [20,54]. On the other hand, the use of urea, which is readily available [42,55] for glycerol carbonylation, appears to provide an attractive production route [56]. Chaves et al. [41] investigated the catalytic activity of tin (II) hydroxides (generated in situ from tin (II) halides) using an air flux system for the removal of ammonia generated by the reaction between urea and glycerol to synthesize GLC, and achieved a GC of 87% and a GLC selectivity of 85% after 4 h at 413 K (Fig. 5 ). However, isocyanic acid (HNC = O) is commonly detected as an intermediate in carbonylation reactions involving urea due to the thermal degradation of urea, and as a result, the use of urea was discontinued [8,35]. The use of alkaline carbonates for GLC production was not cost-effective because the process requires multiple steps [35], which is why alkyl carbonates are preferred [7,8,35]. Furthermore, alkyl carbonate reactions proceed under moderate conditions and do not produce toxic intermediates. Sodium bicarbonate, DEC, and DMC are nowadays employed as carbonate sources for GLC production [57,58]. Tang et al. [58] used CaO loaded with 10% LiCl to produce GLC using DMC as a carbonate source and obtained a GLC yield of 94.19% in 1 h at 65 °C. Mahdi et al. [57] attempted GLC production using sodium bicarbonate over treated clinoptilolite in water, but GC was unsatisfactory (29%), and the reaction proceeded in multiple steps (Fig. 6 ). Thus, DMC and DEC are the most suitable raw materials for GLC production as they provide reasonable GC and high GLC yields though DMC is more attractive due to its lower cost [5,59]. 3 GLC production via the catalyzed transesterification of glycerol The transesterification of glycerol using DMC is the favoured method for GLC production based on considerations of energy requirements and toxicity (Fig. 7 ) [8,35]. The bulkiness of glycerol demands high activation energy, and thus, its reactions are sluggish a,nd hence catalyst is needed [60,61]. Efficient catalysts have been developed, including acid, alkali, and enzyme catalysts, that enable the transesterification of glycerol by DMC in high yields (Table 2 ) [60–62]. Industrial-scale production of GLC requires that the following criteria be fulfilled: (1) the catalyst and reagents used should be cheap and readily available; (2) the catalyst should be efficient and easily separable; (3) the GC should be close to 100% with high selectivity for GLC; and (4) the reaction must be rapid. Screening for the best catalysts amongst those mentioned in Table 2 showed that heterogeneous basic catalysts best met these criteria. 3.1 Homogenous catalysts Various acidic and basic homogeneous catalysts have been tested for their glycerol transesterification potencies. Results show that acid-catalyzed transesterification doesn't result in high GC. Ochoa-Gómez et al. [72] examined the catalytic performances of sulfuric and p-toluenesulfonic acid. The reactions were kinetically controlled and selectivity was disappointing, which was attributed to the cyclization of the methyl glyceryl carbonate intermediate to GLC. Furthermore, acid catalysts are usually avoided due to their corrosive natures. On the other hand, a basic catalyst results in faster conversions as they are swiftly distributed throughout reaction media to form homogeneous mixtures. In addition, bases activate the functional groups of reactants to generate required products [72] (Fig. 8 ). Generally, potassium or sodium carbonates, bicarbonates, alkoxides, or hydroxides of organic ionic liquids (ILs) are used to transesterify glycerol to produce GLC. Moderate working temperatures (50–70 °C) are the most attractive feature of the homogeneous base-catalyzed transesterification of glycerol [24]. However, product separation is problematic for large-scale production, and thus, heterogeneous catalysts are preferred. Pan et al. [24] developed several homogeneous and heterogeneous basic catalysts and reported that Na-doped zeolites had better catalytic efficiencies than CaO, SrO, NaOH, or K2CO3. Moreover, it was found that the large pores of Na-doped zeolites facilitated reactions under mild conditions. Recently, eco-friendly ionic liquids (ILs) have been a focus of research attention [37] and several reports have been issued on the application of ILs as transesterification catalysts [21,29]. Wang et al. [64] reported a GC of 91.8% and a GLC selectivity of 95.5% when guanidine-based ILs were used to catalyze the transesterification of glycerol using DMC. In this work, a series of guanidine-based ionic liquids were synthesized by neutralizing tetramethylguanidine (TMG) with weak protic acid i.e., tetrafluoroethylene (TFE). The catalytic efficiency of [TMG][TFE] IL is attributable to its tunable basicity and the anion-cation cooperative effect [64], as shown schematically in Fig. 9 . Nevertheless, the large-scale use of ILs for glycerol transesterification could not be entertained because of the cost involved. 3.2 Enzyme catalysts Enzymes have garnered much attention as biocatalysts because of their reusability, low toxicity, and functionalities. Du et al. [66] immobilized Candida antarctica lipase B (CALB) on magnetic organosilica nanoflowers, and when used as a biocatalyst it achieved a GC of 94.24% and a GLC yield of 88.66%. The lipase was immobilized on silica nanoflowers (Fig. 10 ) with an extremely high specific surface area. Even after seven production cycles, the CALB@nanoflowers achieved a GC of 79% and a GLC yield of 70.31%. do Nascimento et al. [73] synthesized an enzyme catalyst using a combination of lipases from porcine pancreas and Candida antarctica. Later the lipase combination was immobilized on epoxy resin and used as a reusable biocatalyst in batch and packed-bed reactors. The biocatalyst provided acceptable glycerol to GLC conversion with a GLC selectivity of >99%, which compared well with that of commercial Novozyme 435 (GLC selectivity 88%). Waghmare et al. [59] performed ultrasound-assisted glycerol to GLC conversion using Novozyme 435, which resulted in a GC of 99.75%. The most important benefit of ultrasound was that it reduced the reaction time from 14 h to 4 h. Lee et al. [74] reported a coupled reaction using Novozyme 435 without any solvent that produced biodiesel first and then GLC. This coupling enabled the use of enzymes for the two reactions, which made the process economically viable and less energy intensive, and achieved 97.6% biodiesel and glycerol conversions of 97.6% and 95%, respectively, at a catalyst loading of 25 g/L. A cost study showed that the solvent-free coproduction of biodiesel and GLC was cheaper than that with solvent and resulted in a 3-fold increase in gross margin. Nevertheless, the use of enzymes as biocatalysts for GLC production is restricted by high enzyme costs, enzyme denaturation, and protracted run times. 3.3 Heterogeneous catalyst The problems associated with homogeneous acid-base catalysts can be avoided by using heterogeneous catalysts that can be readily separated from reaction mixtures using simple solid-liquid separation methods. So far, a variety of heterogeneous catalysts have been used for glycerol transesterification/GLC production. Several types of alkali metal/alkaline metal oxide, mixed metal oxide, hydrotalcite, zeolites, and layer double hydroxides have been used to produce GLC by glycerol transesterification (Table 3 ), but alkaline mixed metal oxide catalysts are the most efficient. In addition, some basic organic catalysts have also been used to produce GLC from glycerol. Qing et al. [75] used 1,8-diazabicycloundec-7-ene (DBU) to transesterify glycerol using DMC and achieved a GC and GLC selectivity of 90% and 84%, respectively. Similarly, Wan et al. [76] produced GLC from glycerol and DMC using a DABCO (1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane) embedded porous organic polymer as a bifunctional catalyst and achieved a GC and selectivity of 98% and 95% in 60 min using a catalyst loading of only 0.75 mol%. Although they are easily removed from reaction mixes, heterogeneous catalysts deteriorate over time upon multiple uses due to active site losses. In particular, active sites are lost in alkaline metal and mixed metal oxides due to leaching and phase deformation. This issue can be resolved by selecting solid catalysts with a highly stable lattice structure and an abundance of active sites. Titanium-silica-based catalysts have been reported to be highly stable due to their extensive silicate networks, and as a result, have excellent catalytic activities [67]. Recently, the research fraternity has started to focus on the synthesis of solid catalysts from biomass and waste-derived materials for GLC production from glycerol. These techniques become inherently more cost-effective if bio-glycerol is also used as the reactant [36,77]. Researchers have produced solid catalysts from oil palm fuel ash [35], disposable baby diaper waste [2], Musa accuminata peel ash [8], and 'red mud' waste generated by the aluminum industry [78]. Recently, researchers used hybrid heterogeneous catalysts for the carboxylation of glycerol that reduced reaction time and enhanced GLC yields by providing an enormous reactive interface [37]. Liu et al. [37] synthesized an [APmim]OH/ZIF-8/LDH hybrid catalyst by embedding Ca-Mg-Al hydrotalcite with aminopropyl hydroxide imidazole in ZIF-8 and achieved a GC and GLC yield of 98.6% and 96.5%, respectively. Table 3 enlists the latest advancements made to produce GLC by heterogeneous catalyst-driven glycerol transesterification. 4 Reaction mechanism of glycerol transesterification A thorough understanding of the mechanism of glycerol transesterification is required to design efficient heterogeneous catalysts. Extensive studies have been conducted to understand the mechanism of glycerol transesterification for GLC production [1,3,9,19,82,84,87,89]. Amongst, the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism is the most widely accepted mechanism and involves three steps as shown in Fig. 11 [78,85]. The three steps involve surface adsorption of glycerol on the solid catalyst, bond breakage, and bond formation. Subsequently, end products get desorbed from the surface. Surface adsorption is attributed to interactions between a primary OH of glycerol and a Lewis acid site on the catalyst surface and an interaction between the carboxyl group of DMC and an adjacent Lewis acid site. The interacting primary OH bond of glycerol is then disrupted due to the effects of the Lewis acid-base centers on the surface. Subsequently, the glyceroxide ion formed interacts with the electrophilic carbon center in DMC to produce an intermediate 1-(o-methoxycarbonyl) glycerol complex [85]. In the third step, this complex cyclizes and generates GLC and methanol. There are several studies reported on the study of density functional theory level to categorize the most probable routes to achieve GC was performed [76,86,90]. The assessment of Gibbs free energy value suggested the exothermic reaction with the spontaneous rising of GLC which also further supports the cyclization from intermediate complex as in Fig. 11. In the final step, the active surface of the catalyst is regenerated. Furthermore, the intermediate cyclic product is unstable and it easily undergoes decomposition to form glycidol [28] if the catalyst is excessively basic (Fig. 12 ) [69,75]. An alternative mechanism, known as the Langmuir-Rideal (L-R) mechanism, was suggested by researchers (Fig. 13 ) [91]. Initially, the hydrogens of a primary and the secondary OH of a glycerol molecule interact with adjacent Lewis base surface sites to generate a surface-attached bidentate ligand. The electron-rich secondary oxygen formed then attacks free DMC and subsequent cyclization results in the production of GLC and methanol. Notably, although basic active centers facilitate GLC formation but excessive catalyst basicity can lead to the formation of glycerol dicarbonate (Fig. 14 ). 5 Advancements in the kinetic modeling of glycerol transesterification Advances in the kinetic modeling of glycerol transesterification for the generation of GLC have greatly contributed to the understanding and optimization of the reaction process [78,85]. Researchers have developed more sophisticated and accurate models to capture the intricate dynamics of this event over time. Experimental data, computational techniques, and theoretical insights have all contributed to these developments. Kinetic studies provide insights into the step-by-step reaction mechanism, assisting in understanding the sequence of primary reactions involved in the transformation of glycerol and DMC into GLC. The most accepted reaction mechanism of glycerol transesterification is L-H mechanism where glycerol and DMC get adsorbed on adjacent active centres of solid catalyst followed by surface chemical reactions i.e., dehydroxylation, alkylation, and ring opening to form GLC. Afterwards, products get desorbed from the catalyst surface as presented in Fig. 11. To establish the kinetic model, the steps involved in glycerol transesterification catalyzed by heterogeneous catalysts using DMC, are formulated in the following equations [78,85]. (1) GLY + S ↔ GLY.S (glycerol adsorption on the catalyst surface) (2) DMC + S ↔ DMC.S (DMC adsorption on the catalyst surface) (3) GLY.S + DMC.S ↔ GC.S + ME.S (surface reaction and formation of GLC and methanol) (4) GC.S ↔ GC + S (desorption of GLC from the catalyst surface) (5) ME.S ↔ ME +S (desorption of methanol from the catalyst surface) Considering surface reactions in Eq. The plot of − ln (1- XGLY) vs. t has been shown to be valid for experimental data in several studies [45,47]. To generate such a model, rate constants can be determined experimentally by monitoring the left-out glycerol concentrations at different time intervals and subsequently fitting this data into Eq. (22). To predict the rate of GLC synthesis, one can utilize the rate constant, which is influenced by different factors like catalyst concentration and temperature. Das et al. [78] established a kinetic model based on a pseudo-first-order reaction with a rate constant of 0.1364 s−1 at 75 °C for the transesterification of glycerol. The model applies only to the reaction rate, which is influenced solely by the concentration of glycerol and disregards the effects of DMC concentration and the catalysts used. However, this assumption may not be applicable under different conditions, and thus other factors that might complicate reaction kinetics should be considered. It is worth noting that a first-order kinetic model may not be accurate, hence more complex models based on reaction mechanisms are needed to describe reaction kinetics under different conditions [30]. For example, Kaur and Ali [92] proposed second-order kinetics for glycerol/DMC transesterification catalyzed by lithium zirconate and developed a kinetic model based on a reversible second-order mechanism that considered the effects of temperature, catalyst concentration, and reactant concentration. The derived model was able to predict experimental data obtained from a batch reactor accurately, and the authors concluded that the reaction kinetics were consistent with a mechanism involving homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis. These recent studies reflect the ongoing research interest in the kinetics of glycerol/DMC transesterification. Furthermore, the kinetic study paves the path for the study of reaction thermodynamics. This can be achieved by monitoring the values of rate constants over the length of reaction time at different temperatures. The temperature dependence of k can be deduced using the Arrhenius equation: (23) lnk = ln A − E a / RT … … … … … … … … … … … … … … . Where k is the reaction rate constant; A is the frequency factor or pre-exponential constant (min−1); Ea is the activation energy (kJ/mol); R is the gas constant (8.314 J mol−1 K−1), and T is the reaction temperature (K). Eq. (23) provides the value of the activation energy which estimates the energy barrier that reactants must overcome for the reaction to occur. Esteban et al. [23] established a first order kinetic model for the deactivation of the catalyst in the reaction with DMC. This model contemplated an irreversible reaction with the activation energy of 28.4 ± 1.5 kJ·mol−1 and a deactivation constant of 0.03 ± 0.01 min−1. The lower activation energies indicated faster reaction rates at moderate reaction conditions. Also, thermodynamic functions such as enthalpy change (ΔHo), entropy change (ΔSo), and Gibb's free energy change (ΔGo) can be derived from the Eyring-Polanyi equation [22]. (24) k = k b T h exp ( − Δ G o RT ) … … … … … … … … … … (25) Since, ΔGo = ΔHo - TΔSo. Eq. (24) was modified by taking natural logarithms and substituting ΔG° from Eq. (25) to yield. (26) ln ( k T ) = − ( Δ H ∘ RT ) + [ ln ( k b h ) + Δ S ∘ R ] … … … … … … … … … … … … … … where k is the rate constant (min−1); T is absolute temperature (K), R is the universal gas constant (8.314 J mol−1 K−1), h is Planck's constant (6.626 × 10−34 J s−1), and kb is Boltzmann's constant (1.38 × 10−23 J/K). Pradhan and Sharma [85] determined ΔG° and ΔH° values for the transesterification of glycerol as 16.547 kJ mol−1 and 118.73 kJmol−1, respectively. The positive value of ΔG° confirmed that the transesterification reaction of glycerol with DMC does not occur spontaneously in nature. An external force in the form of heat, catalyst, and so on is required to propel the reaction ahead. Furthermore, a positive value of ΔH°implies that the process is endothermic. Moreover, the turnover frequency (TOF) is a critical parameter in assessing the catalytic activity and performance of heterogeneous catalysts for this reaction. It refers to the number of catalytic cycles completed by a single active site of the catalyst per unit of time. It quantifies the efficiency of the catalyst in converting reactants into glycerol carbonate. To better understand the correlation between number of active basic sites and GC in a continuous flow reactor, TOF can be quantified using the following equation [1]. (27) TOF = 10 4 × X Glycerol × LHSV ( M Glycerol + 3 × M DMC ) × T B … … … … … … … … … … … . . where LHSV is liquid hourly space velocity (h −1); M Glycerol and M DMC are the molecular weights of glycerol and DMC, respectively (g mol−1); TB is the concentration of basic sites on the catalyst (μmol g −1). For a batch reactor, TOF values of catalysts can be quantified using the following equation [85]. (28) TOF = m G l y c e r o l × M G l y c e r o l × X G l y c e r o l 100 × m c a t a l y s t × t … … … … … … … … . . Where mglycerol is the number of glycerol (moles), Xglycerol is the extent of glycerol reacted, Mglycerol is the molecular weight of glycerol, mcatalystis the mass of catalyst used, and t is the reaction time. TOF can be an important factor in catalyst screening, selection, and process design. TOF values are used to assess different catalysts, reaction conditions, and optimization strategies for the production of GLC. It elucidates the catalyst's ability to convert glycerol and DMC into GLC under certain reaction conditions. A higher TOF value implies a more efficient catalyst since it indicates that more catalytic cycles occur within a given interval. TOF values for metal oxides [14], hydrotalcite [93], and mixed metal oxides [15,37,46,58,79,80,93,94] have been reported to fall in the range 0.5–16.11 h−1. Besides TOF, one more important metric i.e., environmental factor (E-factor) of GLC production process from glycerol and DMC using a heterogeneous catalyst must be taken into account to measure the greenness and sustainability of the process [95]. The E-factor assesses the process's environmental impact by calculating the amount of waste generated per unit of product produced. A lower E-factor suggests that the process is more environmentally friendly and resource-efficient. The E-factor can be stated mathematically as: (29) E − factor = Mass of waste generated ( kg ) Mass of GLC produced ( kg ) … … … … … … … … … A lower E-factor implies that the process produces less waste in comparison to the amount of product produced, which is beneficial from both an environmental and economic standpoint. Researchers should strive hard to minimize the E-factor and increase the overall sustainability of glycerol carbonate manufacturing by limiting waste output and optimizing process parameters. 6 Reaction parameters GC and GLC selectivity can be tweaked by modifying reaction conditions. Various factors such as catalyst dose, glycerol to DMC molar ratio, temperature, time, agitation speed, and energy mode massively affect these two variables. Hence these reaction parameters must be optimized to maximize GC and GLC selectivity. Previously, a 'one variable at a time' (OVAT) method was used to optimize reaction parameters. For example, Pradhan and Sharma [85] used the OVAT method to achieve optimum reaction conditions (Fig. 15 ). Today advanced statistical tools like response surface methodology and various designs are used to optimize the reaction parameters where interactive interference of more than two parameters can be monitored. These optimizing techniques help to elucidate optimum conditions and maximize GLC yields. In the following sections, the effects of reaction parameters are discussed in detail. 6.1 Effects of catalyst basic strength and loading Catalysts play a crucial role in promoting the reaction and determining its efficiency. Two key catalyst characteristics that influence GLC production are basic strength and loading. A catalyst with a higher basic strength tends to improve the reaction rate and GLC yield [9]. A more powerful basic catalyst can more efficiently allow bond breaking and bond formation boosting GC to GLC as shown in Fig. 11. However, it should be noted that the basic strength of the catalyst should be optimized. Excessive contact with reactants may cause undesirable side reactions or catalyst deactivation if the catalyst is excessively basic. On the other hand, a catalyst that is too weak may not sufficiently promote the reaction, resulting in lower GLC yield and GC. The basicity of a solid catalyst increases in the order H_<7.24H_<9.80 H_<15.04H_<18.40. Beyond H_>18.4, the catalyst starts to form glycidol (Fig. 12). In addition, pore size plays major role in diffusion, adsorption, and desorption during transesterification and mesoporous solid base catalysts with pore sizes of 2–50 nm have been reported to be most suitable for GLC production [96]. To date, various alkali/alkaline earth metal oxides [7–9,19,35], mixed metal oxides [44], surface-modified zeolite/hydrotalcite/silicate [67,69], mixed metal oxides [84], and layered double hydroxides [82] have been used to catalyze GLC production. Besides, the catalyst loading has a large influence on the reaction kinetics, GLC yield, and selectivity. A higher catalyst loading can generally result in faster reaction rates and potentially higher product yields. This is because additional catalyst gives more active sites for reactant molecules to engage with, increasing the likelihood of successful collisions and product production. On the other hand, excessive catalyst amount use may result in increased production costs, waste generation, or difficulty with catalyst separation and recycling. As a result, an optimal catalyst loading must be found experimentally, taking into account parameters such as maximum GLC production, economic feasibility, and environmental impact [7–9,19,35]. The optimum concentrations of alkali metal and alkaline metal oxides lie between 0.5–5.0 wt.%, whereas for bifunctional acid-base and waste-derived catalysts, concentrations range from 3 to 10 wt.% (Table 3). Overall, balancing both the catalyst's basic strength and loading is essential to achieve efficient and sustainable GLC production with desirable yields and minimal side reactions. 6.2 Effects of molar glycerol/DMC The glycerol/DMC transesterification is a reversible reaction. Thus, Le Chatelier's principle can be applied to shift the reaction in the forward direction [97]. An excessive DMC has the positive effect of shifting the reaction equilibrium towards the GLC product side, but it also has the negative effect of limiting the adequate contact between glycerol and the catalyst due to the increased volume [31,92]. Finding the balance point between these two effects is an important concern. Table 3 shows that the required molar DMC/glycerol is always recorded more than the stoichiometric ratio (i.e., 1:1) as in standard reaction (Fig. 7). It's persistent between 2:1 to 5:1 corresponding to a 15–180 min of reaction time (Table 3). Pradhan et al. [85] detected a marked increase in GC and GLC yield when the molar ratio was shifted from 1:1 to 4:1 (Fig. 7). An optimum DMC to glycerol molar ratio was maintained to maximize GLC production. At an excessive molar ratio, glycerol impedes the reaction, whereas excessive DMC results in the formation of glycerol dicarbonate instead of GLC (Fig. 14). 6.3 Effect of reaction temperature At high temperatures, the equilibrium shifts towards GLC production as it enhances the rate of collisions between reactant molecules to form the GLC [76]. Also, a relatively high temperature boosts the miscibility of DMC and glycerol. Optimizing the reaction temperature is a critical part of GLC process development. It frequently entails a trade-off between obtaining high reaction rates, optimizing product output, and maintaining acceptable selectivity while taking into account the process's economic and safety elements. Moreover, the optimum reaction temperature depends upon the physical properties of the carbonate sources used. Glycerol has a BP of 290 °C and DMC a BP of ∼90 °C, and thus, the reaction temperature should not be higher than the BP of DMC as it can suppress GC. Recently, researchers optimized the reaction temperature according to the carbonate source used and reported a temperature range of 35–140 °C (Table 3) [9,46,85]. Usually, temperatures from 60 to 100 °C have been found suitable for alkali and alkaline metal oxide-based solid catalysts, whereas solid catalysts like hydrotalcite and zeolites require higher temperatures in the 100–150 °C range. 6.4 Effect of co-solvent Co-solvents improve the solubility of glycerol or DMC since these reactants are insufficiently soluble in the reaction medium. These results in improved mixing and more contact between reactants, thereby increasing the reaction rate [76]. GC was reported to be increased by solvents with higher polarities and dielectric constants, presumably because such solvents facilitate product desorption from hydrophilic surface-active sites [47]. Various solvents such as dimethylformamide, dimethyl sulfoxide, acetonitrile, tetrahydrofuran, tert‑butanol, ethanol, and methanol have been used for glycerol/DMC transesterification [57,74]. 6.5 Effect of reaction time The amount of glycerol and DMC transformed into GLC is directly proportional to the reaction time. Longer reaction periods result in higher conversion rates because more reactants have time to participate in the process. Prolonged reaction durations, on the other hand, may result in the creation of undesirable byproducts or side reactions [22,31]. Monitoring the development of the reaction over time can aid in identifying and mitigating the formation of these byproducts. Kinetic studies can help establish the optimal reaction time to achieve the required conversion and yield by providing insights into the pace at which the reaction happens. It is critical to achieve a balance between maximizing conversion and yield and avoiding long reaction times. Generally, solid heterogeneous catalysts require longer reaction times than their homogeneous counterparts due to a larger mass transfer barrier. Researchers have reported reaction times ranging from 15 to 180 min as found in Table 3. Conspicuously, when reaction times are protracted, side reactions reduce GLC selectivity [19]. 6.6 Effect of energy source The rate of the reaction can be influenced by the type of energy source employed. Efficient and controlled energy input can speed up the reaction kinetics, resulting in faster conversion of glycerol and DMC to GLC [26]. Different energy sources can give varying degrees of temperature control. Precise temperature control is critical for maintaining optimal reaction conditions and obtaining the desired product yield and selectivity. The means used to supply energy is a vital consideration. The most convenient mode of energy is direct heating (Table 3), but ultrasonication and microwave energy are the most popular, as they reduce reaction times (Table 3). Teng et al. [98] reported a 5 min reaction time for microwave-assisted glycerol transesterification and a GLC yield of 93.4%. In another study, Wang et al. [83] reported reaction times of 15 min and 50 s for microwave irradiation using TCM and PCM, respectively, resulting same GC of 96.7% and GLC yield of 94.3%. 6.7 Catalyst poisoning and endurance Because of its superior endurance, heterogeneous base-catalyzed glycerol transesterification is chosen over homogeneous transesterification. Highly reusable catalysts make processes economically viable. Table 3 lists the number of cycles achieved using different heterogeneous catalysts. Over time due to deactivation, catalysts used in reaction lose their activity, leading to reduced conversion rates, decreased product yield, and potentially altered selectivity (Fig. 16 ) [85]. Catalyst deactivation is a key issue in the glycerol transesterification process for the manufacture of GLC. Understanding and mitigating catalyst deactivation are critical steps in optimizing the GLC manufacturing process. Several investigations have been conducted to explore the catalyst deactivation mechanism in glycerol transesterification processes. Various approaches, including in-situ spectroscopy, microscopy, and surface analysis have been used to track catalyst changes during reactions and identify critical elements that contribute to deactivation. Notably, solid base catalyzed glycerol/DMC transesterification is not particularly sensitive to moisture or methanol (Fig. 16(b)) therefore these impurities can't be blamed for deactivation [78]. In fact, catalyst deactivation during GLC synthesis can happen through a variety of processes. Catalyst poisoning induced by the deposition of reaction intermediates or byproducts on the catalyst surface, leaching of active species, sintering or agglomeration of catalyst particles, and structural changes in the catalyst generated by reaction conditions are examples of these mechanisms. The primary factors influencing catalyst deactivation are reaction temperature, pressure, reactant ratios, and solvent selection. For example, high reaction temperatures and long reaction periods may hasten catalyst deactivation due to increased sintering or fouling of the catalyst surface. Deactivation susceptibility varies between catalysts. For example, basic metal oxides/mixed metal oxides, hydrotalcites, layered double hydroxides, quaternary ammonium compounds, and zeolites, deactivate by diverse mechanisms as above mentioned. For example, Kaur and Ali [92] reported the leaching of lithium from active lithium zirconate catalyst as the main cause of notable loss in catalytic activity. Similarly, Keogh et al. [4] observed a significant loss in activity upon reuse indicating leaching of the active sodium aluminate phase from the support. Liu et al. [82] proved that the reason for the deactivation of S-CaMgAl metal oxide was a decrease in calcium content attributed to organics adhering to the surface of the catalyst, rather than the leaching of active sites. Alkali metals and their oxides are prone to leaching into the reaction mixture during recycling [19,15] whereas alkaline mixed metals and transition metals and their oxides are considerably more stable due to their compact lattice structures (Table 3). In another study, Devi et al. [67] found out the reason behind the reduction in catalytic efficacy of Ti-SBA-15 and claimed to adsorption of side products on the active catalytic sites which ultimately caused coke formation or amorphous silica species [19]. Researchers have investigated ways for reactivating or regenerating inactive catalysts. To remove accumulated species and restore catalytic activity, procedures such as calcination, washing, or modification of the catalyst surface may be used [35,96]. It has been reported that regenerated solid catalysts exhibit appreciable endurance capacity and have enhanced GCs and GLC selectivity [79,83]. 6.8 Reactor design Reactor design features can ensure high conversion rates and product yields, and suitable designs are essential to produce GLC on an industrial scale [1]. The several factors that should be considered for reactor design are reactant ratios, temperature, pressure, residence time, and mixing efficiency. Reactor design must be optimized to achieve high GLC yields. A well-designed reactor ensures that these factors are controlled, and the chemical reaction proceeds in a controlled environment. Reactant ratios are a critical factor to consider when designing a reactor. The reaction temperature is a primary consideration when selecting an appropriate reactor. Since the transesterification reaction is exothermic the reactor should be designed in such a way to enable temperature control when heat is liberated during the reaction [99]. Both batch reactors and continuous stirred-tank reactors (CSTRs) or fixed bed reactors have been used for GLC production. Conventionally, batch chemical reactors are used to synthesize GLC at a lab scale and raw materials are added piecemeal [18,39,31,91,100,101]. Wang et al. [2] performed glycerol transesterification in a batch reactor using glycerol and DMC and achieved 95.6% GC and GLC yield of 93.6%. Also, reusability was reported 8 times with 92% retention of GC. Batch reactors allow easy changes in reaction conditions and catalysts. Since the reaction takes place in a closed system, batch reactors are suitable for reactions that require the isolation of GLC from the reactants or intermediates. Though batch reactors relatively are easily designed, assembled, and managed, these reactors may have low GCs and GLC yields because of temperature fluctuations [31,102]. Also, each batch time for filling, reaction, product separation, and cleaning, leads to longer cycle times. Besides, variability in reaction conditions and product properties can occur between different batches leading to low precision. This problem is overcome by fixed bed reactors which allow continuous raw material feed and simultaneous product removal [103]. Fixed-bed reactors offer continuous production, which can lead to higher throughput and consistent product quality. As heat removal is generally more efficient in fixed-bed reactors, it enables better temperature control. Hence catalyst deactivation can be minimized due to efficient heat transfer and continuous operation, leading to longer catalyst lifetimes. Nascimento et al. [73] utilized lipases from porcine pancreas and Candida antarctica immobilized on epoxy resins for GLC production under both batch and packed-bed reactors. Under continuous flow conditions, immobilized biocatalyst was able to fully convert GC with >99% GLC selectivity. However, there are drawbacks as well. For instance, they require complex equipment setups and are more challenging to use than batch reactors [103]. Overall, the decision of selection between batch and fixed-bed reactors is determined by the reaction's unique requirements, production volume, product quality, and other considerations. Batch reactors are better suited for small-scale, flexible processes and experimentation, whereas fixed-bed reactors excel in continuous, large-scale production due to improved temperature control and catalyst longevity. Each type of reactor has advantages and disadvantages, and the choice should be based on a comprehensive examination of the process requirements and limits [103]. 7 Future advances and research gap CaO is conventionally used as a solid catalyst for the commercial-scale production of GLC through glycerol transesterification. Its major shortcoming is a short lifetime due to surface contamination and leaching. Solid catalysts with a compact lattice structure are more suitable from a reusability point of view, and alkaline earth metal oxides and their mixed metal oxides are currently the best candidates because their robust lattice structures better prevent leaching. However, as mentioned above, only moderately basic solid catalysts can be used for GLC production. Alkaline earth metal oxides are used to produce GLC efficiently in batch reactors, and when supported on 3D porous networks, such as zeolites or metal-organic frameworks have excellent stability. Furthermore, the generation of efficient solid basic catalysts from waste offers more cost-effective alternatives. GLC yields can be maximized by optimizing reaction parameters using a suitable statistical tool. Various optimization tools like OVAT and RSM can be used to optimize reaction conditions. OVAT is the simplest optimization tool whereas RSM uses BBD and CCD minimizing the number of experimental runs. Additionally, a suitable reactor configuration is crucial for the commercial production of GLC. However, as mentioned above, information on optimizing reactor design is limited. As regards the economic aspects of GLC synthesis, the possibility of coproducing fatty acid methyl ester and GLC from a biomass-derived feedstock using a bifunctional catalyst with high TOF and a suitable reactor could substantially reduce processing costs, as presented schematically in Fig. 17 . The transesterification of triglyceride results in fatty acid methyl ester (FAME) as the main product and glycerol as a side product [2–4,7,35]. Approximately, 10% w/w glycerol is co-produced with biodiesel, and considering the huge market for biodiesel [27] and hence the added value provided by the glycerol produced might substantially increase profitability [104]. However, this would only be possible if the coupled reaction is monitored, and the kinetics and thermodynamics of transesterification reactions, viz. between triglyceride and methanol and between glycerol and DMC, are well understood and determined to be environment-friendly and scalable to industrial levels. 8 Conclusions After conducting an extensive review of existing methods of producing GLC, we conclude that catalyzed glycerol transesterification using DMC as a reagent is the most environmentally friendly and economically feasible route. Both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts can be utilized for glycerol transesterification. Although biocatalysts have been shown to have excellent catalytic characteristics, their high costs and low stabilities militate against their use. Heterogeneous base catalysts with an appropriate number of basic sites are potential catalysts for glycerol carboxylation, and alkali metal oxides, alkaline metal oxides, alkali metal-doped alkaline earth metal oxides, and metal/metal oxides/mixed metal oxides supported on SBA/zeolite/hydrotalcite have all been found to be highly efficient for the production of GLC from glycerol. Furthermore, many other parameters influence reaction, such as catalyst loading (%), DMC/glycerol molar ratio, reaction time, heating method, and reaction temperature. Recently, waste-derived base catalysts have been used to drive glycerol carboxylation and reportedly offer the most economically viable method for producing GLC. In addition, the optimization of reaction parameters markedly increases GC, GLC yield, and the long-term viability of processes. We close by recommending that efforts be made to combine glycerol production and glycerol valorization into a single process based on biomass-derived triglyceride as starting material using a single potent bifunctional catalyst. coredata.dc:description: World biomass valorization has been tremendously boosted by the production of biofuels like biodiesel and hence bio-glycerol, and the bio-glycerol produced can be modified to produce a plethora of useful derivatives. In particular, glycerol carbonate (GLC) is considered one of the most important value-added products due to its many applications in the pharmaceutical and cosmetic industries and others. In this review, we describe heterogeneous catalytic synthetic routes designed to maximize glycerol conversion (GC) and GLC selectivity. Notably, heterogeneous base-catalyzed carboxylation (transesterification) between glycerol and dimethyl carbonate has been identified as a safer and economically viable means of synthesizing GLC. Particularly, alkali and alkaline metal oxide-based hybrid base catalysts are the best candidates for GLC production. Additionally, waste-derived base catalysts are preferred to make sure the process is more cost-effective. Also, only the appropriate amount of basic active sites ends up in the carboxylation of glycerol successfully with methanol as the only side-product. Otherwise, exorbitant basic sites might lead to GLC decomposition to glycidol and reduce GLC selectivity. Later, kinetic and thermodynamic considerations along with TOFs and E-factors are also discussed to provide insight into reaction pathways. This study provides a summary of recent literature on the large-scale production of GLC and of studies on waste-derived solid catalysts, which make the process more cost-effective. In a nutshell, we highlight the environmental and cost benefits conferred by the use of bifunctional efficient heterogeneous catalysts to subsequently produce biodiesel and GLC using coupling transesterification reactions that produce and valorize glycerol simultaneously.
coredata.dc:title: Recent advances in bio-glycerol valorization to glycerol carbonate by heterogenous base-catalyzed transesterification
